content: I am a PhD student in Management Science at the University of Texas at Dallas. My advisors are Milind Dawande and Ganesh Janakiraman. My broad interests are in understanding emerging business models that transform the way we consume goods and services. I am also interested in retail operations, pricing and revenue management, and incentive design problems related to workforce management. My academic training/coursework are in the areas of Optimization, Game Theory and Information Economics, Statistics, Econometrics and Machine Learning.

title: Harish Guda

content:
Hello all!
This is my first post on my new website/blog, thus the title Om Vighnaraja (instead of a Hello World). My hope is to keep y’all updated with content regularly.
Thank you.

title: Om Vighnaraja

summary: We analyze the key property of interventions that make them beneficial to one or all members in an interaction.
title: Seemingly-Beneficial Interventions

summary: We study how an on-demand service platform can coordinate its workforce through forecast-sharing, worker bonuses and surge pricing in a geographically dispersed marketplace using gig-economy workers.
title: Your Uber Is Arriving: Managing On-Demand Workers Through Surge Pricing, Forecast Communication, and Worker Incentives

summary: We study the role of guaranteed support prices in agriculture under supply yield uncertainty and demand-side budget constraints.
title: An Economic Analysis of Agricultural Support Prices in Developing Economies

summary: We study a variant of the classical appointment scheduling problem, where idling is not allowed, but advancing a patient's surgery is allowed. We show that the Shortest-Variance-First (SVF) rule is optimal for our variant.
title: Optimal Policy for a Stochastic Scheduling Problem with Applications to Surgical Scheduling
